clinical_study.brief_title: Clinical Study of TEAS Intervention in Relieving Anxiety Before Thoracoscopic Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Clinical Study of TEAS Intervention in Relieving Anxiety Before Thoracoscopic Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: At present, effective clinical intervention methods for anxiety mainly include anti-anxiety drug treatment, psychotherapy and acupuncture-related treatment. Most of the anti-anxiety drugs are benzodiazepines, which have a very direct sedative effect, but frequent use is prone to drug dependence, excessive sedation and other shortcomings. Psychotherapy is expensive and not well accepted by the general public. Acupuncture-related treatments are adopted by more and more doctors and patients due to its advantages of small adverse reactions and low costs. Acupuncture has the effects of relieving anxiety and reducing pain, and can play a great role in the perioperative period. Systematic reviews have found that acupuncture has a significant effect on anxiety, and it is better than the drug control group. At the same time, the acupuncture effect can also relieve postoperative nausea and vomiting and prevent postoperative discomfort. However, although acupuncture is used to relieve anxiety in neurology and neurosurgery, onychomycosis, gynecology and other clinical departments and has drawn considerable conclusions, acupuncture intervention relieves anxiety during the perioperative period of thoracic surgery. There is still a lack of systematic research on the efficacy evaluation. Transcutaneous Electrical Acupoints Point Stimulation (TEAS) technology originated from traditional Chinese acupuncture and moxibustion. It is a type of peripheral stimulation that delivers low-frequency pulse currents to the human body through the skin to achieve a therapeutic effect. In contrast, TEAS has the advantages of being non-invasive, easy to repeat, safe, and low in cost, and is easy to be accepted by patients. Therefore, replacing the traditional acupuncture technology with TEAS technology has a more unique advantage in clinical application. As chest CT examinations become more common, the detection rate of early lung cancer has gradually increased in recent years. As the mainstream treatment of thoracic surgery, thoracoscopic surgery is widely used clinically. Therefore, how to make the majority of patients undergoing thoracoscopic surgery have a better diagnosis and treatment experience is an urgent clinical problem.

detailed_description.textblock: At present, video-assisted thoracoscopy is the most commonly used surgical method in thoracic surgery. Compared with traditional open thoracic surgery, this minimally invasive technique has the advantages of small surgical mouth, less bleeding, and quick recovery. Both have greatly benefited. However, after being admitted to the hospital for surgical treatment due to illness, the change of identity and environment makes the patient inevitably anxious, and affects the patient's psychology and physiology throughout the perioperative period. Therefore, perioperative anxiety is a common phenomenon in patients undergoing surgical treatment, and the incidence is about 11%-80%. As far as thoracic surgery patients are concerned, before surgery, patients are mainly worried about the risks of surgery, anesthesia accidents and the quality of life in the future, and after surgery, they will worry about their own recovery and follow-up treatment. This kind of uneasy feeling can cause bad mental state and produce different degrees of negative emotions. On the one hand, it may lack a positive attitude towards postoperative treatment. On the other hand, patients are prone to expand normal postoperative discomfort such as wound pain. Additional use Analgesic drugs. At the same time, the anxiety reaction itself can affect the body's physiological and psychological functions through the central nervous system, endocrine, and immune system, leading to insomnia, acute delirium, arrhythmia and other adverse events, and aggravating postoperative complications, directly affecting the prognosis and prognosis of patients. Rehabilitation not only harms the patient's body and mind, but also increases the extra hospitalization costs due to the prolonged treatment time. Studies have also shown that preoperative anxiety will increase the amount of intraoperative anesthetic drugs, delay the recovery after anesthesia, and directly aggravate the side effects of anesthetics. Therefore, perioperative anxiety has received extensive clinical attention.

primary_outcome.measure: Score change of Generalized Anxiety Scale (GAD-7)
primary_outcome.description: Add the scores of each of the 7 items to get the total score; among them, 0-4 points for no anxiety, 5-9 points for possible mild anxiety, 10-14 points for possible moderate anxiety, 15 Scores above are likely to have severe anxiety. The GAD-7 scores' Change from the third day before surgery and the last day before surgery will be recorded and compared.

intervention.description: Acupoint selection (positioning strictly in accordance with the National Standard of the People's Republic of China GB 12346-90 "Acupoint Locations"): Baihui, Yintang, Hegu, and Taichong, both sides are taken, TEAS is performed every day for three days before surgery, and Han's acupoint nerves are used Stimulator (HANS200A produced by Beijing Huawei Co., Ltd.), sparse and dense wave type, frequency 2/100 Hz (Hz). The center of the electrode is aligned with the acupuncture point, the corresponding lead is connected to the stimulator, the current intensity is 10mA, and all acupoints are stimulated for 30 minutes every day for three days before the operation.

Comprehensive evaluation of cardiopulmonary function, preparation of respiratory tract, active treatment of coexisting diseases before operation, correction of water and electrolyte disorders and hypoproteinemia before operation. To prevent cross-infection during the operation, the intraoperative blood volume should be supplemented within the tolerance of cardiac function, the tissue perfusion should be sufficient, and the infusion should be uniform. Strengthen respiratory care after operation, prevent cardiovascular complications, pay attention to the speed and amount of blood transfusion, encourage early activities, promote lung expansion and prevent thrombophlebitis.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Those diagnosed as lung nodules requiring thoracoscopic surgery.
- Those who have no previous mental illness and have not used anti-anxiety or psychotropic drugs within 2 weeks.
- Those who have clear consciousness, normal understanding, no expression barriers, can cooperate with treatment and have signed an informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who have received TEAS treatment in the past.
- Patients with skin infections in local meridian points.
- Patients with upper or lower limb nerve injury.
- Patients who have participated in or are participating in other clinical trials one month before enrollment.
